title: American History Highlights
description: Journey through key moments in American history, from the Revolution to the Space Age.

questions.question: In what year did the United States declare its independence from Great Britain?
questions.explanation: The Declaration of Independence was adopted by the Continental Congress on July 4, 1776, primarily authored by Thomas Jefferson.

questions.question: What was the name of the ship that brought the Pilgrims to America in 1620?
questions.explanation: The Mayflower carried 102 passengers from England to Plymouth, Massachusetts. The voyage took about 66 days across the Atlantic Ocean.

questions.question: Who gave the famous 'I Have a Dream' speech during the civil rights movement?
questions.explanation: Martin Luther King Jr. delivered the 'I Have a Dream' speech on August 28, 1963, at the March on Washington. Over 250,000 people attended the historic event.

questions.question: The Civil War was fought primarily over which issue?
questions.explanation: The American Civil War (1861-1865) was fought primarily over the issue of slavery and whether it would expand into new territories and states.

questions.question: What event triggered the United States' entry into World War II?
questions.explanation: Japan's surprise attack on Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, on December 7, 1941, led the U.S. to declare war. President Roosevelt called it 'a date which will live in infamy.'

questions.question: Which amendment to the Constitution gave women the right to vote?
questions.explanation: The 19th Amendment was ratified on August 18, 1920, granting women the right to vote after decades of activism by suffragists like Susan B. Anthony and Elizabeth Cady Stanton.

questions.question: What was the name of the program that sent American astronauts to the Moon?
questions.explanation: The Apollo Program ran from 1961 to 1972. Apollo 11 successfully landed the first humans on the Moon in July 1969. In total, 12 astronauts walked on the lunar surface.

questions.question: Who was the commanding general of the Continental Army during the American Revolution?
questions.explanation: George Washington commanded the Continental Army from 1775 to 1783. His leadership during the harsh winter at Valley Forge became legendary.

questions.question: What famous speech begins with 'Four score and seven years ago'?
questions.explanation: Abraham Lincoln delivered the Gettysburg Address on November 19, 1863. The speech was only about 270 words long but is considered one of the greatest speeches in American history.

questions.question: Rosa Parks became a civil rights icon when she refused to give up her seat on a bus in which city?
questions.explanation: On December 1, 1955, Rosa Parks refused to give up her bus seat to a white passenger in Montgomery, Alabama. Her arrest sparked the Montgomery Bus Boycott, a pivotal moment in the civil rights movement.

questions.question: Which territory did the United States purchase from Russia in 1867?
questions.explanation: The U.S. purchased Alaska from Russia for $7.2 million, about 2 cents per acre. Critics initially called it 'Seward's Folly' after Secretary of State William Seward, but it proved to be an incredible bargain.

questions.question: What was the significance of the Battle of Gettysburg in 1863?
options: It was the turning point of the Civil War
It was the first battle of the Civil War
It was the largest naval battle
questions.explanation: The Battle of Gettysburg (July 1-3, 1863) is widely considered the turning point of the Civil War. The Union victory ended General Lee's second invasion of the North.

questions.question: The Gold Rush of 1849 drew thousands of settlers to which state?
questions.explanation: The California Gold Rush began in 1848 when gold was found at Sutter's Mill. By 1849, about 300,000 people had migrated to California, earning them the nickname 'forty-niners.'

questions.question: Which act, signed in 1964, outlawed discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin?
questions.explanation: The Civil Rights Act of 1964, signed by President Lyndon B. Johnson, was landmark legislation that ended segregation in public places and banned employment discrimination.

questions.question: What document begins with the words 'We the People of the United States'?
questions.explanation: The United States Constitution begins with those famous words. It was signed on September 17, 1787, at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia and remains the supreme law of the land.
